block.p: Tracey Yvette Lewis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George R. Lewis of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Dr. Don Gregory Elligan, a son of Deborah Elligan of Chicago and the late Duke Elligan. The Rev. Dr. James A. Forbes Jr., the senior minister of Riverside Church, officiated at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

Mrs. Lewis-Elligan, 30, is a Ph.D. candidate in child and family studies at Syracuse University. Next month she is to become an assistant professor of sociology at Salem State College in Massachusetts. She graduated from Hampton University in Virginia and received a master's degree in psychology from the New School for Social Research.

Tracey Yvette Lewis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George R. Lewis of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Dr. Don Gregory Elligan, a son of Deborah Elligan of Chicago and the late Duke Elligan. The Rev. Dr. James A. Forbes Jr., the senior minister of Riverside Church, officiated at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

Mrs. Lewis-Elligan, 30, is a Ph.D. candidate in child and family studies at Syracuse University. Next month she is to become an assistant professor of sociology at Salem State College in Massachusetts. She graduated from Hampton University in Virginia and received a master's degree in psychology from the New School for Social Research.

Her father is the president and chief executive of the Philip Morris Capital Corporation in Stamford. Her mother, Lillian Lewis, is a director of the Domus Foundation, a youth service organization in Stamford; she was formerly a special education teacher and a rehabilitational education counselor.

Dr. Elligan, 32, is the vice president for behavioral health at the Harvard Street Neighborhood Health Center, a clinic in Boston. He is also an instructor in psychiatry at the Boston University School of Medicine. He is a graduate of Oberlin College and received a master's degree in psychology from Fisk University in Nashville and a Ph.D. in clinical psychology from Fairleigh Dickinson University. His mother owns a duplicating and bookbinding service in Chicago. His father was a drug abuse counselor in Chicago.
